input:
from setuptools import setup, find_packages

setup(
    name='py2dataset',
    version='0.1',
    packages=find_packages(),
    package_data={
        '': ['*.json', '*.yaml'],  # The patterns to match for included data files
    },
    url='https://github.com/jeffmeloy/py2dataset',
    license='MIT',
    author='Jeff Meloy',
    author_email='jeffmeloy@gmail.com',
    description='A tool to convert Python code into structured datasets',
    long_description=open('README.md').read(),
    long_description_content_type="text/markdown",
    install_requires=[
        'networkx', 
        'matplotlib',
        'pyyaml', 
        'ctransformers'
    ],
    classifiers=[
        'Development Status :: 3 - Alpha',
        'Intended Audience :: Developers',
        'License :: OSI Approved :: MIT License',
        'Programming Language :: Python :: 3.8',
    ],
    python_requires='>=3.8',
)

output:
The file py2dataset.setup.py is a configuration file for the Python package manager, setuptools. It is used to build, install and distribute software packages. The setup() function in this file is where the package metadata such as name, version, description, long_description, etc are being declared.

This file also includes the find_packages() call which will automatically include all sub-packages and their contents when the package is built. This is a common practice to keep the namespace clean and organized.

The 'package_data' section in setup is used to specify files or directories that should be included as part of the package. In this case, we are including json and yaml files from any directory.

url, license, author, author_email, description, long_description and long_description_content_type are all standard fields for PyPI and other package index sites to display when a user is browsing or searching for your package.

install_requires lists the Python packages that are required by this package. In this case, we're requiring networkx, matplotlib, pyyaml and ctransformers as they are dependencies of the package.

classifiers is a list of classifiers that help other people find your project. The Development Status classifier is set to Alpha which means it's in development and not ready for use by most users.

python_requires indicates that this package requires Python 3.8 or higher.
